    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
Sunday evening in Andalucía saw one of the world's most illustrious football clubs, Barcelona, take on Granada CF at the Nuevo Estadio de Los Cármenes in a La Liga encounter steeped in history and expectation. By the time the final whistle was blown, the scoreline read 4-1 in favor of the visitors, Barcelona, but the encounter was brimmed with action, passion, and football of the highest quality.

The match started with Granada CF taking the initial kick-off. Within mere seconds, the ball was out of play, and Granada took a throw-in that set the initial pace of the game. It was clear from the beginning that both teams were eager to control possession and dictate the rhythm, leading to numerous throw-ins and out-of-play moments within the first couple of minutes. Barcelona, renowned for their tiki-taka playing style, tried to settle into their passing rhythm, but the early stages were slightly fragmented.

The first significant attempt on goal came in the 11th minute when a Barcelona player made an impressive run into the box, but unfortunately for the Catalans, the shot was mishit and flew high over the bar. Granada CF's defensive discipline was tested early, and they responded by clearing their lines consistently, exemplified by repeated clearances.

The game saw an early casualty as Rafinha of Barcelona picked up an injury at around the 13th minute. Showing clear signs of discomfort, he was eventually replaced by Paco Alcácer in the 17th minute—a substitution that later turned out to be fortuitous for Barcelona.

Midfield battles were intense, with occasional fouls breaking the flow. Granada CF's robust defending led to multiple indirect free-kicks for Barcelona. In the 24th minute, Paco Alcácer narrowly missed what could have been the opening goal, his powerful shot smashing against the crossbar. Neymar, believing he had scored moments later, saw his jubilation cut short as the linesman flagged for offside.

Guillermo Ochoa, the Granada goalkeeper, proved his mettle between the posts with a series of impressive saves. He thwarted Neymar’s effort easily after an edge-of-the-box shot in the 25th minute, followed by an exceptional save to deny Luis Suarez a minute later. Suarez’s powerful shot seemed destined for the back of the net, but Ochoa's acrobatics kept the match scoreless.

In the 27th minute, Sergi Roberto of Barcelona received the first yellow card of the match for a tackle deemed too aggressive by the referee Santiago Jaime Latre. As Barcelona continued their relentless attack, it seemed only a matter of time before they breached the Granada defense.

That moment came in the 44th minute. Luís Suarez, ever the predator in front of goal, seized on a precise through ball from Jordi Alba. With a composed and clinical finish from the edge of the area, Suarez buried his shot into the back of the net, leaving Ochoa no chance and breaking the deadlock to put Barcelona 1-0 up. Granada CF kicked off immediately but soon enough, the referee blew the whistle signaling the end of the first half.

The second half saw Granada initiating changes, with Lucas Alcaraz substituting Victorien Angban with Jeremie Boga, likely in search for renewed vigor on the pitch. Barcelona also demonstrated their attacking intent straight away, with Paco Alcácer testing Ochoa almost immediately after the restart with a shot destined for the bottom right corner. However, Ochoa’s superb save kept the scoreline intact at that moment.

Just four minutes into the second half, deploying one of their first significant offensives, Granada struck back. Matthieu Saunier set up Jeremie Boga, who, showing great composure, managed to find space amidst the Barcelona defenders and unleashed a low shot that clipped off the left post and into the net, bringing the hosts level at 1-1.

Barcelona's response was prompt and forceful. The Catalans proved their class and soon regained the lead. In the 64th minute, following fluid build-up play, Luis Suarez, this time assuming the role of provider, set Paco Alcácer free inside the box with an immaculate pass. Alcácer finished neatly, slotting the ball into the right side of the net to restore Barcelona’s lead at 2-1.

Ochoa continued to be the busiest player for Granada, making crucial saves to keep his team competitive. However, as the game progressed, Granada found themselves increasingly on the defensive, managing sporadic forays into the Barcelona half, often ending without significant danger due to offside traps or well-timed interceptions by the Barcelona defense.

Granada, already facing a formidable opponent, suffered a further blow when Uche Agbo was sent off in the 76th minute after receiving his second yellow card for a bad challenge. Down to ten men, Granada’s task became more daunting, and Barcelona capitalized on their numerical advantage.

The second half also saw several substitutions, with Andrés Iniesta replacing André Gomes to inject fresh creativity into Barcelona’s midfield. Barcelona’s persistence and attacking finesse paid off once more in the 83rd minute. Ivan Rakitic, taking advantage of a fortunate deflection, netted from the edge of the box to extend Barcelona’s lead to 3-1.

Later, a remarkable moment of skill and teamwork resulted in another goal for Barcelona. In the dying moments of the match, Paco Alcácer again turned provider, playing a delightful pass into the box for Neymar. The Brazilian made no mistake from close range and fired the ball home to make it 4-1 to the visitors. This goal cemented the victory for Barcelona and underscored their dominance in the match.

The match had a few more sequences of play leading to throw-ins and clearances, but Granada could do little to change their fate. Despite their spirited performance and occasional flashes of brilliance, the gulf in class was evident as Barcelona executed their game plan to perfection. As the final whistle blew, the score stood at 4-1 in Barcelona’s favor—a result that solidified their standing in the league and showcased their attacking prowess.

Throughout the match, individual brilliance blended seamlessly with collective effort for Barcelona. Suarez, Alcácer, Neymar, and Rakitic all featured prominently on the scoresheet, each demonstrating why Barcelona remains one of the most formidable forces in European football. On the other hand, Guillermo Ochoa’s commendable goalkeeping performance for Granada provided several highlights, as he tirelessly worked to contain the Catalan onslaught. 

In conclusion, Granada CF vs Barcelona was a thrilling encounter marked by strategic prowess, individual brilliance, and a narrative that reflected the essence of football – a game of moments, skill, and endurance. Barcelona’s 4-1 victory not only underscored their clinical edge but also reflected their resilience and tactical acumen, navigating through injuries, substitutions, and moments of adversary with aplomb. For Granada, despite the loss, the fixture was a testament to their fighting spirit, exemplified by the moments of stout defending and a well-taken goal by Jeremie Boga. All in all, it was a match that delighted football purists and fans alike, exemplifying the beautiful game's unpredictability and sheer drama.
